title: Optimal Energy Dispersive X-ray Microanalysis of Low-Z Elements
content: Reducing the incident beam energy brings with it many advantages for energy dispersive electron beam X-ray microanalysis of low-Z elements [1-3]. For low-Z elements, which have characteristic X-ray lines only in the sub-1 keV range, the effects of absorption can dominate the analysis. At 20.0 keV, it is easy to overlook the O K signal from SiO2 because the X-ray is so strongly absorbed. However, by lowering the beam energy to 5 keV, the beam no longer penetrates so far into the sample and absorption is greatly reduced. The O lines now are easily distinguished over the continuum. Figure 1 shows φ(ρz) curves which demonstrate the difference in relative absorption between SiO2 at 5 keV and 20 keV. The red curve represents the generated signal as a function of mass-depth. The blue curve represents the emitted signal. At 20 keV, the emitted signal is substantially below the generated signal particularly at larger depths while, at 5 keV, the difference is less significant.
